data.title: Intellisense space issue
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.8.0-insider (a28dc215af3146d827d4b2f46a3191e2d487efde, 2016-11-10T07:05:12.185Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.1.0

---

Steps to Reproduce:

Typescript file:

```ts
test()

/**
 * This
 * 
 * is a test
 */
function test() {

}
```

Notice how popup shows 'isa test' when you hover `test()` in first line:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1723815/20180212/879501c6-a727-11e6-8e0b-e8eeee4ab149.png)

data.title: Word wrap falsly applied on load
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Sierra

Steps to Reproduce:

Default settings only

1. Open a file with a really long line (over 300 chars)

Expected: The line should not wrap as `editor.wordWrap` is set to `false` by default

Actual: The line does wrap. Toggling word wrap on and off again fixes the issue.

I was able to work around this by setting `"editor.wrappingColumn": -1`, but I'm not sure why this is necessary given the default setting of `editor.wordWrap`.

data.title: Update to electron 1.4.x
data.body:
**Frameworks**
* V8 (52 => 53)
* Chrome (52 => 53)
* node.js (6.5.0 => no change)
* libuv (1.9.1 => no change)

**Fixes**
* [x] Accessibility: Selected tree item not read from screen reader (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/13104)
* [x] Crash when closing window with custom title (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/15154)
* [x] Windows: no output from CLI causing us to use cat.exe as workaround
* [x] Unable to save CPU profiles (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/13704)
* [x] New fullscreen windows opens as tabs (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/13550)
* [x] Folder path truncated after resizing window (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14558)
* [x] Menu actions affect wrong window/project if menu in second window is clicked while menu active in first window (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/12312)
* Font blurry issues on Windows when using >100% DPI setting

**Features**
* [x] Can leverage newly introduced `ELECTRON_NO_ASAR` environment variable for our processes
* [x] Could enable HC theme by default when detected in Windows (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/15360)
* New net module to run HTTP(s) requests through Chrome ([docs](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/master/docs/api/net.md))
* `guestinstance` in webview ([docs](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/master/docs/api/web-view-tag.md#guestinstance))

**Bugs**
* [x] Drag image looks completely broken now from the tree
* [x] Need to verify AA works properly across OS

data.title: tree-work should be in `window` namespace
data.body: The [proposed tree API](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/vscode.proposed.d.ts#L15) should be defined in the `window` name, but in `workspace`. The former is UX'is things (like status bar, editors eat) whereas the latter is for things that are related to currently open folder (like documents, search, settings)

data.title: First instance of Code opens full-screen, subsequent instances open in smaller windows
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

In a command window if I run `code .` it opens code fullscreen (which I want; it's how I left it). If I then run `code .` again from another command window, it opens in a small window (not full screen).

This is 100% reproducible for me. It's incredibly minor, but it is a little annoying (it's an extra step to maximise every time I do it) and it does feel a bit wonky.

data.title: Layer breakers here and there
data.body:
We have a way of [structuring](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/Code-Organization) our code in layers and target runtimes. That's why our code is organised into folders like `common`, `browser`, `node`, `electron-main`, and `electron-browser`. The idea of [target environments](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/Code-Organization#target-environments) is to have easily reusable code. It also means, code from a *lower* layer isn't allowed to use code from a *higher* layer. 

We don't always stick to that rule and therefore I have added a **tslint**-rule. It's not yet enabled because there are still too many violations. This issue is a collection of all of them. If you are assigned make sure to move your code into the right folder.

To run the check yourself do this

* open [tslint.json](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/tslint.json#L25) and set `layering` to `true`
* run `gulp tslint`

After a minute or two, it will produce output like this

```
src/vs/workbench/workbench.main.ts:15:1:Bad layering. You are not allowed to access 'electron-browser' from here, allowed layers are: [common, browser, workbench]
src/vs/workbench/workbench.main.ts:16:1:Bad layering. You are not allowed to access 'electron-browser' from here, allowed layers are: [common, browser, workbench]

data.title: Relative path to workspace in title bar
data.body:
Since a few days it seems to be possible to show the full path in the title bar in the insider builds.  
This is already really helpful when figuring out where I am currently at in my codebase but most of the times the full path seems to be too much information in my opinion. A solution to this problem could be another option to only show the path starting from the workspace directory.

Example: I have a folder called `my-app` which is located in the folder `~/Development`. When I open a file located in `src/foo/bar/index.js` for example, I can either display the full path (`~/Development/my-app/src/foo/bar/index.js`) or just the filename (`index.js`).  
With the proposed addition the title could be reduced to `src/foo/bar/index.js` which in a lot of cases contains the information I am looking for when I look at the path of a file.

data.title: Bug in parsing embedded language
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8 Insider I'm working on a Vue extension: https://github.com/octref/vetur For this code: ```vue
``` I'm using this rule: ```yaml vue-directives: name: meta.directive.vue begin: (?:\b(v-)|(:|@))([a-zA-Z\-]+)(?:\:([a-zA-Z\-]+))?(?:\.([a-zA-Z\-]+))*\s*(=) end: (?<='|") captures: '1': {name: entity.other.attribute-name.html} '2': {name: punctuation.separator.key-value.html} '3': {name: entity.other.attribute-name.html} '4': {name: entity.other.attribute-name.html} '5': {name: entity.other.attribute-name.html} '6': {name: punctuation.separator.key-value.html} patterns: - name: source.directive.vue begin: '"' beginCaptures: '0': {name: punctuation.definition.string.begin.html} end: '"' endCaptures: '0': {name: punctuation.definition.string.end.html} patterns: - include: source.js - name: source.directive.vue begin: '''' beginCaptures: '0': {name: punctuation.definition.string.begin.html} end: '''' endCaptures: '0': {name: punctuation.definition.string.end.html} patterns: - include: source.js ``` I'd expect only `(a == b) ? x : y` get tokenized by the embedded js rule. However, VSCode marked the last double quote as double quotes in js and continued to parse the rest as string. ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4033249/20171271/beeba0e6-a6e4-11e6-9e1a-8d43a7342a2d.png) Sublime: ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4033249/20171722/d9d9fdce-a6e6-11e6-8016-31257d879c1a.png)

data.title: VSC should not allow the bottom of the document to scroll away from the bottom of the window
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.7.1 (02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44, 2016-11-03T13:46:00.226Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|lex|luniclynx|0.1.0|
|typescript-hero|rbbit|0.9.0|

---

When scrolling my documents in VSC, the very bottom of the document can be scrolled entirely to the top of the window (leaving a blank window.) I have never seen this behavior in any other GUI app (compare any text editor, web browser.. anything, really).

It's an annoyance, but possibly something easy to fix?

data.title: Running Tasks Are Using Incomplete Export Path
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.7.1 (02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44, 2016-11-03T13:46:46.244Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-43-generic
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|output-colorizer|IBM|0.0.8|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.1.0|
|docthis|joelday|0.3.5|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.2.1|
|gitflow|vector-of-bool|0.1.0|

---

I have a commander.sh file which will run another .sh file based on the parameter given. It was running fine until yesterday. When I ran it, it said:

running command$ ./commander.sh compile-backend
TASK BEGIN...
Thu Nov 10 14:03:02 WIB 2016
compile-backend
TASK FINISHED!
./install-model.sh: line 1: npm: command not found
./install-service.sh: line 1: npm: command not found
./commander.sh: line 43: npm: command not found
Thu Nov 10 14:03:02 WIB 2016

When I printed the export PATH the running task was not have a configured PATH variable that's why it can't found npm and other cli commands. I am using Linux Mint and I had run the updater prior this error.  So probably because of linux's system update but I still don't know how to fix this problem. Can anyone help? The only way that I know is to clone the VSCode source code and try to debug the problem myself but the npm install on the repo is very big and took a long time and still not finished by the time I am writing this issue

data.title: Shortcut key for Git is inconsistent on Mac
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0 insiders
- OS Version: macOS

From https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/aff2353a3873f58f2436215c2827fafbcdad5eaa/src/vs/workbench/parts/git/browser/gitWorkbenchContributions.ts#L492 I saw

```
win: { primary: KeyMod.CtrlCmd | KeyMod.Shift | KeyCode.KEY_G },
linux: { primary: KeyMod.CtrlCmd | KeyMod.Shift | KeyCode.KEY_G },
mac: { primary: KeyMod.WinCtrl | KeyMod.Shift | KeyCode.KEY_G }
```

We are using `WinCtrl` on Mac while on Windows/Linux it's `CtrlCmd`, which makes Git the only that uses `Ctrl` instead of `Cmd` as modifier. Any catch behind it?

data.title: Investigate BackupService listening to ILifecycleService.onWillShutdown instead of being called from TextFileService
data.body:
From https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/14115#discussion_r87145853

@bpasero 

> @Tyriar can you explain again why the backup service cannot participate in the shutdown and do its work there?

@Tyriar

> A few reasons:
>
> - `TextFileService` depends on `BackupService.cleanupBackupsBeforeShutdown` because it needs to clean up backups.
> - `BackupService` needs to trigger `TextFileService.confirmBeforeShutdown`.
> - Even if they were separate, there would need to be some communication between the 2 services. Depending on what `BackupService` does, it may need to not give a prompt even if there are dirty files for example.
>
> If you have any ideas how to get around this nicely that would be great :smiley:

- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Windows 7

Updating extensions becomes difficult as user needs to restart VSCode for each extension update.

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1.  Click Update for all extensions with update available.
2.  Click Reload for one of the updated extensions,  VS Code restarts.

**Desired Behavior**

VS code should reload all extensions which have been updated.

**Actual Behavior:**

Only the clicked extension is reloaded, remaining new extensions show update button.
User needs to update and reload each extension individually

data.title: Investigate regression to `code <folder> <path>` in hot exit
data.body:
From @bpasero in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/14115#discussion_r87144113

> @Tyriar something is very broken here in this case:
> * have a window with a folder open that has a dirty untitled file
> * close that window without saving
> * from the command line start `code <path to that folder> <file in that folder>`
> => you are not seeing the file being opened 
> => instead the dirty untitled file is opened

> This is related to the comment I made in that one issue where I said that your restore logic will not work if someone opens Code like that.

- VSCode Version:
- OS Version:

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open folder (git) on remote server
2. make edits
3. save (ctrl + s)

Expected Results:
File should save and remain open

Actual Results:
File saves but close (part of the time)
